results.title: Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.

constellations_primary.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_primary.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

results.description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). From a technologically advanced but nightmarish future to mad scientists and the first robot in a feature, Metropolis has influenced so much of what we see on-screen today. At two hours and 33 minutes, it was also one of the longest films ever made at the time. Critics were sceptical at first, but it’s now considered groundbreaking, particularly for its production design and costumes. Those two elements have inspired C-3PO in Star Wars, Kylie Minogue’s robotic stage costumes and the futuristic city in Blade Runner. If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.

results.title: Sergei Eisenstein
results.brief_description: Sergei Eisenstein was a Soviet director and film theorist who pioneered the use of montage and changed how we see cinema. Eisenstein believed that juxtaposing different film shots created meaning, manipulated emotions and communicated ideas through visual metaphors.

constellations_primary.name: Auteurs, influence and inspiration
constellations_primary.description: A tradition of influence and inspiration beginning with Eisenstein.

results.description: Sergei Eisenstein was a Soviet director and film theorist who pioneered the use of montage and changed how we see cinema. Eisenstein believed that juxtaposing different film shots created meaning, manipulated emotions and communicated ideas through visual metaphors. By the time he released his second film, Battleship Potemkin (1925), he’d put the theory into practice: he assembled over 1,300 shots in an 82-minute film to tell the story of a shipboard mutiny, propelling the action through his new cinematic technique. Montage was unlike anything seen before and influenced not just directors like Alfred Hitchcock, Brian De Palma and Martin Scorsese but also the rapidly edited style of advertising and music videos.

results.title: Giovanni Pastrone
results.brief_description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria.

constellations_primary.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_primary.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

results.description: Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. All of these elements were on show in his epic 1914 film, Cabiria. The film broke new artistic ground by using special effects to re-create the eruption of Mount Etna and the naval battle of Syracuse, but its biggest legacy is the ‘Cabiria’ shot: the tracking shot. Pastrone mounted a camera on a dolly to trail the action in a scene, and this new technique was quickly adopted by filmmakers at the time.

results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films.

constellations_primary.name: Voice and the moving image
constellations_primary.description: Sound changed cinema, but it wasn't always welcome, but it hasn't stopped people aspiring for the spotlight.

results.title_for_label: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
results.description:
Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films. Their first film, Those Who Love (1926), was funded by their family and hailed as a “dazzling triumph” by publication Everyone’s.

Influenced by Hollywood melodramas and German Expressionism, the sisters’ films featured emotionally honest characters and broke with traditional gender norms. Fox Films even offered McDonagh and her sisters the chance to make movies in Hollywood, but they decided they “would end up very small fish in a big pond” so stayed in Australia, where they worked up until the mid-1930s.

results.title: Lois Weber
results.brief_description: Lois Weber was one of the most daring filmmakers of Hollywood’s silent era. A leading director, screenwriter, producer and actor, she helped establish the use of split-screens to show simultaneous action in her 1913 film Suspense, and she experimented with synchronised sound.

constellations_primary.name: Lois Weber and the split-screen
constellations_primary.description: Lois Weber was the third filmmaker to use split screens to show simultaneous action, helping establish it as part of cinematic language, particularly its use in thrillers. It's since been taken to extremes by auteurs and videogames.

results.description:
Lois Weber was one of the most daring filmmakers of Hollywood’s silent era. A leading director, screenwriter, producer and actor, she helped establish the use of split-screens to show simultaneous action in her 1913 film Suspense, and she experimented with synchronised sound. In an estimated 200 to 400 films, Weber explored social issues such as poverty, capital punishment, drug abuse and abortion. Her controversial film Hypocrites (1915) featured the first full-frontal nude scene.

“She writes her own stories and continuity, selects her cast, directs the pictures, plans to the minutest detail all the scenic effects, and, finally, titles, cuts and assembles the film. Few men have assumed such responsibility.” – Aline Carter, Motion Picture, 1921

results.title: Edwin S Porter
results.brief_description: Edwin S Porter pushed the boundaries of film editing and was central to developing the new screen language. He created gradual transitions and dissolves between scenes and perfected cross-cutting to show simultaneous action.

constellations_primary.name: Gunslingers, good fellas and flea bags
constellations_primary.description: Explore how a 1903 western changed the course of filmmaking and videogames by breaking the fourth wall.

results.description:
Edwin S Porter pushed the boundaries of film editing and was central to developing the new screen language. He created gradual transitions and dissolves between scenes and perfected cross-cutting to show simultaneous action.

In The Great Train Robbery (1903), Porter cross-cut 10 different locations to show multiple, interlinked scenes in an 11-minute spectacle unlike anything seen on-screen before. Featuring villainous bandits, heroic lawmakers and innocent bystanders, the film was action-packed, and Porter’s editing mastery propelled the excitement to the final iconic scene – a bandit firing point-blank at the startled audience. Later, Porter pioneered changing shots in a single scene, and he’s even credited with identifying the ‘shot’ as the basic unit of a film.

results.title: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
results.brief_description: Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks.

constellations_primary.name: Clones, doubles and doppelgangers
constellations_primary.description: Multiple characters and doubles materialise in this Constellation inspired by the pioneering special effects of Georges Méliès.

results.title_for_label: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
results.description:
Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks like multiple exposures, split-screens, time-lapse photography, dissolves and hand-colouring. He even accidentally invented the jump cut when his camera jammed.

Between 1896 and 1913, Méliès directed over 500 films. He described them as “little abracadabras” and they were truly magical, inviting audiences on A Trip to the Moon (1902), into The Kingdom of Fairies (1903) and to enjoy a chorus of decapitated heads.

results.brief_description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio. She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

constellations_primary.name: Lost and found
constellations_primary.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

results.description:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.

To find our more about Alice Guy-Blaché, rent Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché on our streaming platform, Cinema 3.

results.title: Auguste and Louis Lumière
results.brief_description: In 1895 Auguste and Louis Lumière patented the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity, but its biggest achievement was projection.

constellations_primary.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_primary.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

results.description:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.

results.title: Thomas Alva Edison
results.brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

constellations_primary.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_primary.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

results.description: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.
